title: Enacts the farmworkers fair labor practices act, granting collective bargaining rights, workers' compensation and unemployment benefits to farmworkers
summary: Enacts the farmworkers fair labor practices act: grants collective bargaining rights to farm laborers; requires employers of farm laborers to allow at least 24 consecutive hours of rest each week; provides for a 10 hour work day for farm laborers; requires overtime rate at one and one-half times normal rate; makes provisions of unemployment insurance law applicable to farm laborers; provides sanitary code shall apply to all farm and food processing labor camps intended to house migrant workers, regardless of the number of occupants; provides for eligibility of farm laborers for workers' compensation benefits; requires employers of farm laborers to provide such farm laborers with claim forms for workers' compensation claims under certain conditions; requires reporting of injuries to employers of farmworkers.

         day  of  rest  each  week,  and  including  farm  laborers  within the
         provisions pertaining to overtime compensation and unemployment insur-
         ance, and regulating the farm employment of  certain  employees  whose
         earning capacity is affected or impaired by youth or age, and granting
         collective bargaining rights to certain farm laborers and establishing
         an  advisory  committee  on collective bargaining; to amend the public
         health law, in relation to the application of the sanitary code to all
         farm and food processing labor camps for migrant workers; and to amend
         the workers' compensation law, in relation to the eligibility of  farm
         laborers  for  disability benefits and the provision of claim forms to
         farm laborers injured in the course of employment and in  relation  to
         service as farm laborers

    4    S 9. The labor law is amended by adding a new section 704-b to read as
    5  follows:
    6    S  704-B.  UNFAIR LABOR PRACTICES; AGRICULTURE. 1. IT IS THE POLICY OF
    7  THE STATE TO PROTECT THE RIGHTS OF FARM LABORERS WITHOUT CAUSING IMMEDI-
    8  ATE AND IRREPARABLE HARM TO EMPLOYERS. IN RECOGNITION  OF  THE  NEED  TO
    9  AVOID  INTERRUPTION OF THE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION OF CROPS WITH A SHORT
   10  PEAK HARVEST SEASON, THIS POLICY IS  BEST  ACHIEVED  BY  PROVIDING  FARM
   11  EMPLOYERS  AND  THEIR  EMPLOYEES WITH A SHORT TEMPORARY PERIOD TO SETTLE
   12  THEIR LABOR DISPUTE WITHOUT CAUSING IMMEDIATE OR IRREPARABLE HARM TO THE
   13  EMPLOYER.
   14    2. DEFINITIONS. WHEN USED IN THIS SECTION THE TERMS:
   15    (A) "SHORT PEAK HARVEST SEASON" MEANS THE PERIOD FOR FRUITS AND  VEGE-
   16  TABLES  THAT  HAVE  A  MAXIMUM  HARVEST PERIOD OF NO MORE THAN SIX WEEKS
   17  DURING WHICH SUCH AGRICULTURAL PRODUCT IS HARVESTED FOR SALE, AS  DETER-
   18  MINED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND MARKETS.
   19    (B)  "WORK STOPPAGE" MEANS ANY STRIKE, OR CONCERTED CESSATION OR SLOW-
   20  DOWN OF WORK BY EMPLOYEES.
   21    (C) "LOCKOUT" MEANS A WORK STOPPAGE DURING WHICH AN EMPLOYER  PREVENTS
   22  EMPLOYEES FROM WORKING.
   23    3. IN THE EVENT THAT THE BOARD AND ITS EMPLOYEES RECEIVE NOTICE THAT A
   24  LABOR DISPUTE HAS ARISEN BETWEEN A FARM EMPLOYER THAT WILL OR MAY RESULT
   25  IN  A  WORK  STOPPAGE  OR  LOCKOUT, THE BOARD SHALL IMMEDIATELY INITIATE
   26  SETTLEMENT PROCEEDINGS UNDER SECTION SEVEN HUNDRED TWO-A OF  THIS  ARTI-
   27  CLE.
   28    (A)  AFTER THE INITIATION OF SETTLEMENT PROCEEDINGS, ANY WORK STOPPAGE
   29  OR LOCKOUT SHALL CEASE FOR A PERIOD OF NOT MORE THAN TWENTY-ONE DAYS  IF
   30  BOTH OF THE FOLLOWING CIRCUMSTANCES EXIST:
   31    (I)  THE  WORK  STOPPAGE OR LOCKOUT OCCURS DURING A SHORT PEAK HARVEST
   32  SEASON; AND
   33    (II) THE WORK STOPPAGE OR LOCKOUT WILL CAUSE IMMEDIATE AND IRREPARABLE
   34  INJURY, LOSS OR DAMAGE TO THE EMPLOYER.
   35    (B) DURING SUCH TWENTY-ONE DAY PERIOD, BOTH PARTIES SHALL  ENTER  INTO
   36  GOOD  FAITH NEGOTIATIONS TO SETTLE THE LABOR DISPUTE, WHICH PERIOD SHALL
   37  BE REFERRED TO AS A COOLING OFF PERIOD.
   38    (C) THE BOARD SHALL CONDUCT AN IMMEDIATE  AND  EXPEDITED  FACT-FINDING
   39  HEARING  TO  DETERMINE  WHETHER THE CIRCUMSTANCES UNDER PARAGRAPH (A) OF
   40  THIS SUBDIVISION EXIST. EACH PARTY SHALL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO  SUBMIT
   41  WRITTEN  AND ORAL TESTIMONY AT THE HEARING. THE BOARD SHALL NOT BE BOUND
   42  BY TECHNICAL RULES OF EVIDENCE PREVAILING IN COURTS OF LAW OR EQUITY.
   43    (D)  THE  BOARD  SHALL  ISSUE  ITS  DETERMINATION  IN  WRITING  WITHIN
   44  FORTY-EIGHT  HOURS OF THE CONCLUSION OF THE HEARING, WHICH SHALL INCLUDE
   45  FINDINGS OF FACT AND A RATIONALE FOR ITS DETERMINATION. A  COPY  OF  THE
   46  BOARD'S DETERMINATION SHALL BE PROVIDED TO EACH PARTY WITHIN TWENTY-FOUR
   47  HOURS.
   48    (E)  FOR PURPOSES OF THIS SECTION, AN EMPLOYEE WHO IS ABSENT FROM WORK
   49  WITHOUT PERMISSION, OR WHO ABSTAINS WHOLLY OR  IN  PART  FROM  THE  FULL
   50  PERFORMANCE  OF  HIS  OR HER EMPLOYMENT DUTIES WITHOUT PERMISSION ON THE
   51  DATE WHEN A WORK STOPPAGE OR LOCKOUT OCCURS SHALL BE  PRESUMED  TO  HAVE
   52  ENGAGED IN SUCH WORK STOPPAGE OR LOCKOUT.
   53    4. IF EITHER PARTY IS FOUND TO BE IN VIOLATION OF THE BOARD'S DETERMI-

actClause: AN ACT to amend the labor law, in relation to allowing farm workers one day of rest each week, and including farm laborers within the provisions pertaining to overtime compensation and unemployment insurance, and regulating the farm employment of certain employees whose earning capacity is affected or impaired by youth or age, and granting collective bargaining rights to certain farm laborers and establishing an advisory committee on collective bargaining; to amend the public health law, in relation to the application of the sanitary code to all farm and food processing labor camps for migrant workers; and to amend the workers' compensation law, in relation to the eligibility of farm laborers for disability benefits and the provision of claim forms to farm laborers injured in the course of employment and in relation to service as farm laborers
